709326f.text:
Sixth Ave, north from Greenwich Ave, showing 8th Street elevate( station. Jefferson Market Police Court is seen in left foreground.

709331f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue at N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue, showing bed of Minetta Creek and site of old Jefferson Market.
December 31, 1929.
P.L.Sperr,Photographer.
The same from Greenwich Avenue and viewing northward. Demolition in the foreground is for the new Detention H:ouse for Women.
1929.

709322f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth AVe., at the S.W. corner of Greenwich Ave., as viewed from the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line, showing the automobile parking space, ocoupying that area. Also shown (left), aro the rears of 3-story houses, facing on Gay Street, and bearing Nos. 13 to 19 (left to righth. Adjoining same, and northward, is a 7-story warehouse (H, Lehlen & Co0w. facing on and bearing Nos. 12-10 Christopher Street. No. 8 Christ opher Street, is the Pirates Den. Prominently shown (left to right) are the 12-story Heptagon Building (Nos. 147-153 Waverly Place), and a 17-story apartment housef No. 45 Christopher Street), between Waverly Place and Seveuth Ave. South.
October 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2 & 3)
A set of 2 views showing the same location at an earlier date and
prior to clearance.
October 11, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

709338f-a.text: Jefferson Market Court House. About 1935. 6h Ave. & Grenwich Ave. at Christopher and W.9h St.

710992f-b.text:
(1)
8th Street (formerly also known as Clinton Place), south side, we Yrom 24 West 8th Street to Sixth Avenue. This is one of the principal shop and restaurant sections of Greenwich Village. Between 30 and 34 West 8th Street is the upper end of Macdougal Street. In the background is the Sixth Avenue Elevated Station 28 West 8th Street, occupied by the Jumble Shop Restaurant, has i its time housed various notable people. James Fraser, the scul lived here; and the buffalo nickel was designed here by his wif Laura Fraser. Edwin Arlington Robinson wrote some of his poetr
at this address.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, west from No. 20. Note the demolition at the S.W. co of MacDougal Street. "Gonfarone's," a famous restaurant occupied th site for years. For further data upon same, see the New York Times
May 30, 1937.

709321f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from between W. 8th and 9th Streets. The open area in the foreground is formed by the meeting of the aforementioned thoroughfares and Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue. This is to be identified as "Village Scuare". View 3 shows the W. 8th Street station that was formerly located here. Intersection in the left foreground is W. 9th Street and
the bank is at the N. E. corner thereof.
March 8, 1939
March 10, 1939
Januare 17, 1930 '
P. L. perr

709320f-b.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave.. at the convergence of Greenwich Ave. (foreground) and Christopher Street on the west side of same, viewing eastward to show the Eighth Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Buildings shown across same are on the east side of the AVe. from 8th (right) to 9th (left) Streets. Note in the left foreground the foundation work for the new Womens Detention Prison (former site of
the old Jefferson Market).
December 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A northward view on the east side of Sixth Ave., from West 8th Street.
May 11. 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Similar to No. 1, but viewed northeastward on Christopher Street. On the extreme left is Greenwich AVe., and a corner of the new Women's
Prison.
September 8, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
